title: How to Dispose of Wood

steps.headline: Collect and sort out yard waste over 3 to 4 ft (0.91 to 1.22 m) long.
steps.description: City waste collection services place a limit on what they are willing to take. The wood typically has to be ⁄2 to 4 in (1.3 to 10.2 cm) thick as well. You could contact local waste disposal services to see if they will accept larger branches. Most yard waste, including twigs, branches, and firewood, can be disposed of through these services. The rules for disposing of yard waste vary from place to place. Contact your local waste management service for more information. Your local government’s waste management office can also help. If you have a long piece of wood that would be too long for regular disposal, try cutting it down to size.

steps.headline: Tie the wood into bales 4 ft (1.2 m) long and 2 ft (0.61 m).
steps.description: Stack the wood in small piles to knot together with rope or twine. Make sure each bundle is easy to pick up and move. If they are the wrong size, the disposal service may refuse to take them.Avoid tying the wood up with other material, such as tape or nylon twine. They have to be sorted out of the woodpiles, so most collection services don’t want them.

steps.headline: Place the wood out with your regular garbage service for collection.
steps.description: Wait until the night before the pickup date to move the bundles out into the open. Place them next to any garbage bags you’re also getting rid of. Keep everything on the opposite side of the lawn from your mailbox, no more than 2 ft (0.61 m) from the curb.To get rid of wood bundles this way, you will have to be subscribed to a waste management service.

steps.headline: Schedule pickup for wood bundles over 3 to 4 ft (0.91 to 1.22 m) long.
steps.description: Contact the city garbage disposal service, if your area has one, or call a private company. Ask what kind of options they have for getting rid of big branches or other yard waste. They may have you rent a dumpster. You may also be able to drive the wood to a waste disposal center and drop it off there.Some services allow you to request separate disposal. As long as you call them and schedule a pick up, they take the waste for free. If you rent a roll off dumpster or container, it usually costs up to $200 USD. Depending on where you live, you can often take up to 2,000 lb (910 kg) of debris to a landfill for free, making it a more affordable option.

steps.headline: Mulch wood to reuse it as a fertilizer.
steps.description: Try renting a wood chipper. Feed the branches slowly and carefully into the chipper to shred. Then, scatter the wood chips around growing plants to help keep the soil moist and weed-free. If you have lots of large branches to get rid of, mulching can be worth the cost..Check with local hardware and power equipment rental stores. They charge $200 to $400 per rental. If you’re unwilling to cover the rental cost on your own, ask some of your neighbors to join in too.

steps.headline: Burn wood in a fireplace or fire pit to get rid of it.
steps.description: Before deciding to burn yard waste, check local regulations to make sure it’s legal. Then, select a spot away from flammable surfaces. Surround the area with 10 ft (3.0 m) of soil or stone to ensure the fire can’t spread. Wait for a day that isn’t very windy, then light the wood and stand back.Burning wood isn’t ideal since it’s bad for the environment and destroys resources that could be used elsewhere. However, it’s fine if you don’t have any other alternative. If you’re unable to dispose of the wood yourself, see if your neighbors can use it. Some people will even pay for scrap wood.

steps.headline: Sort the untreated lumber from pressure-treated and painted wood.
steps.description: Treated wood often has a green color that fades to gray as it ages, or it will have an identifying ink stamp like "L PP2." Painted wood is easier to spot, and it can't be recycled unless you can scrape the paint off. The chemicals from these types of wood cannot be removed and are harmful to the environment, so they are disposed of separately. Products like particleboard and plywood are considered to be treated. They should also be taken to a disposal center instead of recycled or burned. Note that any painted wood from before 1978 could have lead in it. Let the disposal service know so it gets tested and sent to a safe place. If you hired a contractor to do construction work, they are responsible for sorting and removing wood waste. You only have to do it if you did the work on your own.

steps.headline: Pull nails out of the wood using a claw hammer.
steps.description: Turn the wood so the nail heads are face up. Grip them with the claw end of the hammer to tug them out. If that doesn’t work, you may be able to take them out with a pry bar or another tool. The nails have to be removed in advance, especially if you’re planning on recycling the wood.Remove what you’re able to. If you’re unable to get a nail stuck deep inside of the wood, let the disposal service know. As long as the nail isn’t sticking out in a dangerous way, you can usually get rid of the wood. Some recycling centers do accept wood with nails. For clarification, contact recyclers in advance and ask what their policies are. Most of them don’t have the ability to remove and process nails.

steps.headline: Bundle untreated wood with twine and place it with yard waste.
steps.description: Group the wood into bundles about 2 ft (0.61 m) tall and 4 ft (1.2 m) wide, then knot them together thoroughly. Place the wood out the night before your scheduled garbage pickup date. Keep the wood next to your trash no more than 2 ft (0.61 m) from the curb. Your city or private garbage disposal service will take it next time a truck stops by.Note that the rules vary from place to place. Most places let you bundle lumber with yard waste. Others may force you to take it to a disposal facility.

steps.headline: Take treated and painted wood to a disposal facility.
steps.description: To find a suitable facility, contact local waste management services or your government’s waste management department. They will tell you where to transport the wood. Always call in advance to let the facility know that you’re coming. When you’re ready to get rid of the wood, drive it to the facility.If you have more wood than you can fit in your car, rent a truck or contact a hauling company. Another option is to take a little bit at a time. Landfills and disposal facilities often charge a flat rate, such as $60 per 200 lb (91 kg) of waste. However, some areas let you get rid of a set weight of debris for free before they start charging you. Note that some communities have waste disposal events where you can dump scrap wood for free. Contact your local waste management department for more information.

steps.headline: Reuse scrap wood to repurpose it and save money.
steps.description: There are many projects you can create out of old building materials, from planter boxes to a deck. If you don’t have a use for your old scrap wood, give it to someone else or take it to a recycling or salvage center in your city.Salvaged-wood dealers charge a lower fee than other disposal services, so look into giving them untreated lumber. Note that treated and painted wood cannot be burned or turned into mulch. Some pieces of wood can be reused, but wear a dust mask when cutting it.

steps.headline: Contact a waste management service to request a free pickup.
steps.description: Call the waste management service you use to regularly dispose of trash. Some cities also offer free furniture disposal, so call your local government’s waste management office for more information. If such a service is available, you must schedule a pickup date, then leave the furniture out by the curb. Take advantage of any free disposal services offered in your area. Some city services let you get rid of bulk items up to 5 times a year. Some charities also pick up furniture for free. Smaller items can often be fit into trash bags for your normal weekly waste disposal service. However, this isn’t the best way to get rid of pressure-treated or painted wood. To prevent chemicals from leaching into the ground, reuse these goods or dispose of them separately.

steps.headline: Hire a bulk disposal service if free pickup isn’t available.
steps.description: You may have to rent a roll-off dumpster, which is good if you have lots of things to get rid of. Another option is to schedule a pickup date with a disposal service and then leave the furniture near your front curb. You could also take the wood to a landfill yourself. Get in touch with waste management companies or your government’s waste management department to discuss these options and disposal fees.The transportation fee for these services varies a lot depending on what you’re getting rid of and how far it needs to be moved. Roll-off dumpsters usually cost at least $200, but junk removal services tend to start at $75. Another option is to take your items directly to a disposal facility. Call the facility to ask about their policies first. You will have to drive the items there yourself, so you may need to rent a trunk to move big pieces of furniture.

steps.headline: Reuse old wood items by giving them away.
steps.description: If you have furniture or household items in good condition, try taking them to a secondhand store. Call the store in advance to schedule a drop off, then drive the items there yourself. Another option is to give them to neighbors or family members.Most types of wood furniture and household goods are made with treated wood or have been painted. Since they cannot be recycled, the best way to dispose of them is to reuse them. For example, wooden toys and quality furniture like desks are usually made with treated wood or have paint on them. Find someone to take them off your hands. If you have no other option, ask a disposal service what to do with them. Reselling is a good way to reuse wood objects. You could also refinish older items to renew them and earn more.

steps.headline: Recycle wood items if you don’t wish to reuse them.
steps.description: Separate the wood from any other components, such as upholstery. That way, you can recycle each part separately. Search online for wood recycling centers in your area or contact a waste management department for more information. You could also incorporate untreated wood into your own new craft project. Keep in mind that treated and painted wood won’t be accepted by a recycling facility. You may be able to repurpose these pieces at home, but avoid burning them. Patio furniture is an example of recyclable wood. Patio furniture is usually made with untreated hardwood that resists water, so it is safe to take apart and reuse.
